com.hippikon.security
Class DefaultPermissionSet

java.lang.Object
  com.hippikon.security.DefaultPermissionSet
All Implemented Interfaces:
PermissionSet, java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
MutablePermissionSet
public class DefaultPermissionSet
extends java.lang.Object
implements PermissionSet

The DefaultPermissionSet class provides a default implementation of the PermissionSet interface using bitwise operations to manipulate permission flags.

This class may be used by Policy implementations in order to create permissions defined within a PolicyStore.

A permission set is defined using one byte, with each bit representing a permission flag:

Bit Name Hex Abbrev
8Reserved0x00-
7Reserved0x00-
6Reserved0x00-
5CREATE0x10i
4READ0x08r
3WRITE0x04w
2CONTROL0x02c
1DELETE0x01d

Examples:

Flags Binary Integer Hex
---i----00010000160x10
---ir---00011000240x18
---irwc-00011110300x1E
----rwcd00001111150x0F
----rwc-00001110140x0E
----rw--00001100120x0C
----r---0000100080x08
-----w--0000010040x04
------c-000001020x02
-------d0000000110x01
--------0000000000x00

Note there are no mutator methods that allow application logic to alter permissions obtained from a PolicyStore. This ability is restricted to Policy implementations via the MutablePermissionSet class, instances of which may be obtained from the Policy superclass only.

The class also defines a mechanism of combining multiple PermissionSet objects that performs a logical OR operation to find the complete set of permissions of a single user accessing a ProtectedResource within an AuthorizationContext. The user may play multiple roles or have some special association with the ProtectedResource (such as the instance creator).

JDK 1.2.2

DefaultPermissionSet

protected DefaultPermissionSet(java.lang.String aclString)
                        throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

Parameters:
aclString - a String representation of the permission set
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the string passed into the constructor is < 5 chars in length

DefaultPermissionSet

protected DefaultPermissionSet(PermissionSet perms)
                        throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new DefaultPermissionSet object with values based on another PermissionSet object. Based on the return values of the canXXX() methods, each flag in the bitset will be enabled or disabled accordingly. This effectively creates a deep-copy of a PermissionSet.

Parameters:
perms - a PermissionSet object
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the permissions set coming into the method is null.

DefaultPermissionSet

public DefaultPermissionSet()
Creates a new DefaultPermissionSet with no flags enabled.

addPermissions

public void addPermissions(PermissionSet perms)
                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Adds a PermissionSet to affect the state of the PermissionSet instance using an OR rule. This method should be used to strengthen a PermissionSet with another PermissionSet.

For example, if a PermissionSet instance had only the READ flag set, and a READ/WRITE PermissionSet was passed into this method, the PermissionSet instance would be set to READ/WRITE.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Returns a Unix style string representation of the PermissionSet using the following abbreviations:

i = canCreate() returns true
r = canRead() returns true
w = canWrite() returns true
c = canControl() returns true
d = canDelete() returns true
- = canXXX() returns false

For example, a permission of read and write would be represented by the String "-rw--"

getIntVal

protected static int getIntVal(java.lang.String acl)
                        throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Given a string representation of a set of permission flags, returns the integer value. The acl string value must be 5 characters in length and use the irwcd format for CREATE, READ, WRITE, CONTROL and DELETE flags.

Parameters:
acl - a String representation of an access control list entry
Returns:
the int value representing the String acl passed in
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the string representation is < 5 chars in length
